snippet.textDisplay:
That Square magic is still there.
Take a look at Final Fantasy XIV, for instance. Fantastic storytelling, really memorable characters, and an insane soundtrack that has both quality *and* quantity. If I'm going to be honest, as much as I love Legend of Mana, it.... hasn't aged well at all. Only Mana games I think that have are Secret of Mana and Seiken Densetsu 3.
snippet.textOriginal:
That Square magic is still there.
Take a look at Final Fantasy XIV, for instance. Fantastic storytelling, really memorable characters, and an insane soundtrack that has both quality *and* quantity. If I'm going to be honest, as much as I love Legend of Mana, it.... hasn't aged well at all. Only Mana games I think that have are Secret of Mana and Seiken Densetsu 3.

snippet.textDisplay: Lmao The World Ends With You is better than most old Square games (except Final Fantasy IX, VI, and VII) and Kingdom Hearts is a great series. The others are debatable, but they're by no means 'bad' games.
snippet.textOriginal: Lmao The World Ends With You is better than most old Square games (except Final Fantasy IX, VI, and VII) and Kingdom Hearts is a great series. The others are debatable, but they're by no means 'bad' games.

snippet.textDisplay:
As much as I like old Square, Squeenix still has a ton of good games. Just to list a few:

Bravely Default/Second
The World Ends With You
Kingdom Hearts
I Am Setsuna
Final Fantasy XV (though some might disagree more on this one)

And there are still others, but this is just off the top of my head. They still make good games, with the exception of crap like Life is Strange, which "hella" sucks ass.
snippet.textOriginal:
As much as I like old Square, Squeenix still has a ton of good games. Just to list a few:

Bravely Default/Second
The World Ends With You
Kingdom Hearts
I Am Setsuna
Final Fantasy XV (though some might disagree more on this one)

And there are still others, but this is just off the top of my head. They still make good games, with the exception of crap like Life is Strange, which "hella" sucks ass.

snippet.textDisplay:
What is really important is the art direction, which is how the individual art assets combine together to realize the creative vision of the game authors. Sadly, many modern games drop this out entirely and go with uninspired but cutting edge visuals (and blow the entire budget on this or marketing...). 

Sometimes limitations can bring out the best in a given medium.
snippet.textOriginal:
What is really important is the art direction, which is how the individual art assets combine together to realize the creative vision of the game authors. Sadly, many modern games drop this out entirely and go with uninspired but cutting edge visuals (and blow the entire budget on this or marketing...). 

Sometimes limitations can bring out the best in a given medium.

snippet.textDisplay: Because the first thing people do when comparing new games to old is bring up graphics. Graphics are important, yes and they can add to a game. SupaWaffle is merely stating that it's not graphics that make the game, but the way in which art, story, and experience come together. Graphics don't make a game, and neither does art or story. A lot of people like to complain about graphics in the older games.
snippet.textOriginal: Because the first thing people do when comparing new games to old is bring up graphics. Graphics are important, yes and they can add to a game. SupaWaffle is merely stating that it's not graphics that make the game, but the way in which art, story, and experience come together. Graphics don't make a game, and neither does art or story. A lot of people like to complain about graphics in the older games.

snippet.textDisplay: I only played the game once (rented it) but I clipped all the art I could find out of magazines. I LOVED the style. Shinichi Kameoka has since become one of my favorite illustrators and influenced my own art career quite a bit. You're right, supawaffle, a games art direction is SO much more important than a powerful graphics engine.
snippet.textOriginal: I only played the game once (rented it) but I clipped all the art I could find out of magazines. I LOVED the style. Shinichi Kameoka has since become one of my favorite illustrators and influenced my own art career quite a bit. You're right, supawaffle, a games art direction is SO much more important than a powerful graphics engine.
